Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: New Methods for Genomic Analysis of Noninvasive Samples
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this study is to develop novel methods for generating and analyzing genome-scale data from biological samples that have been collected in a noninvasive manner. Noninvasive samples are often the only type of biological sample available for natural populations, especially in endangered or threatened species, but they yield tiny quantities of low-quality DNA. Noninvasive genetic analysis techniques have changed little in the past twenty years, meaning that the genomic revolution has not yet arrived for species for which only noninvasive samples are available. This study will address this problem by producing new lab protocols for increasing and purifying the DNA yield from noninvasive samples to a level appropriate for genomic analysis, and by developing new software to analyze the resulting genomic data. It will validate these approaches by comparing genomic data from noninvasive samples to data from high-quality DNA samples, using data for a known pedigree from the well-studied wild baboons of the Amboseli basin in East Africa.

This project will result in a major leap forward in tools for studying the genomics of many different species and sample types. Publicly available protocols and software will be released, which can be used to investigate evolutionary and population history in species for which such studies were previously impossible. It will also provide societal benefits in the form of tools for assessing the conservation status of vulnerable species. Finally, both graduate and undergraduate students will be trained as collaborators on the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last twenty years, the capacity to generate genetic data from low quality or noninvasively collected tissue samples has revolutionized the study of genetics, evolution, and ecology in natural populations. These methods have been especially important to understanding the genetics of endangered species and large mammals for which other forms of sample collection are difficult or impossible. However, the methods themselves remain labor- and time-intensive, and they have been sorely in need of updating to keep up with the rapid progress now standard in genomics. The main goal of this study was to address this need by developing novel methods for generating and analyzing genome-scale data from biological samples collected in a noninvasive manner.

 

Specifically, we produced new wet lab protocols for increasing and purifying the DNA yield from noninvasive samples to a level appropriate for genomic analysis. We also produced accompanying software to reconstruct pedigree relationships from the resulting data, thus providing the research community with analysis tools to facilitate use of the wet lab methods. We showed that both approaches produce accurate and reliable results by comparing genomic data collected from noninvasive samples to data obtained from high-quality samples, using information for a known pedigree from a well-studied wild baboon population in the Amboseli region of East Africa. Using the same population, we also showed that low coverage genome-wide sequencing data, of the type most readily obtainable from our new methods, could be used to estimate the ancestry of different segments of DNA from around the genome (“local ancestry”). Together, our results make genomic analysis accessible to a much broader set of species and settings, with particular benefits for evolutionary and population genetic analysis and conservation biology.

 

Broader impacts of the work include provision of training opportunities at multiple levels of scientific research, including two graduate students, a post-doctoral fellow, and two research technicians at Duke. We also have provided resources and training to visiting graduate students from other universities. In addition, all resources generated through this research, including data, code, and detailed protocol information, are freely available to the public.
